title: Universal Studios Movie Analysis Package
text:
Here is a website all about my package for STAT 386
Documentation here
Get Started here
Review the technical report here

title: Technical Report
text:
Project Objectives: The objective of this project is to find what features determine high grossing movies. In other words, how would I make a movie, and when would I release it in order to return the highest amount of revenue?
Key Findings: In total, we found that making a movie that appeals to everyone, is released in the summer, and has a high starting budget, results in the highest revenue. Specifically, making a PG movie using Digital Animation in the genre of Adventure or Action, which appeals to those inside and outside the US will result in the highest overall revenue. This movie should be made with the largest production budget possible, (to get the best talent), and should be released in the summer, specifically on whatever weekend has the best chance of creating the highest opening weekend revenue possible.
Actionable Recommendations: Create a movie as described in the Key Findings above.

title: Technical Report
text:
Project Context
Motivation: Identify best way to create a movie, and the best time to release a movie to maximize revenue.
Stakeholders: Business/Board of Trustees/Boss
Success Criteria: Identify distinct features that are important for overall movie revenue

title: Technical Report
text:
Data Sources

Primary dataset:
List of movies: Universal Movies from 2020-2029 and Universal Movies from 2010-2019
Financial Data for movies: The Numbers
Supplementary data: These were the only sites used TODO - describe any external references
Data access notes: Wait five seconds between requests, all information is open access with no licenses needed.

title: Technical Report
text:
Methodology
TODO - outline collection scripts/APIs 1. Data acquisition: Used common web scraping techniques to obtain data from Wikipedia and The Numbers. Specifically the libraries: requests and beautiful soup.

Cleaning pipeline: `


Changed Release Date into a datetime object.
Changed all revenue numbers from strings containing $ to proper integers.
Changed runtime from a string to an integer
Changed all None values to np.Nan
Removed all extraneous information, specifically
Who released the movie and what type of release it was (for both video and theater release date)
Percentage of total gross for opening weekend
Production budget as related to worldwide box office
MPAA Rating specifics
Created a profits column by taking Total Box Office Revenue - Budget
Also created a Year, Month, and Season column based upon release date
This was validated by checking that all columns were of specified types and manually viewing the dataset, and all was as expected
A separated csv was created for Machine Learning Analysis wherein the target, Total Box Office Revenue, was analyzed as a log of the original target due to the skewness of the target data, this separate csv, ml_movie_data.csv, also removes all non-numeric columns.
ml_movie_data.csv is the transformed version of movie_data.csv
This was validated by checking the new transformed column


Analysis workflow:


Correlate all the data to see what has an effect on income
Find the NAs for reference
Plot the money against one another to check for anomalies
Find the average revenue for each year and then plot it for clearer visuals
Find the statistics for some of the means
Plot the categorical data with regards to the Inflation Adjusted Domestic Revenue

“We used some basic analysis such as correlation, plots to visualize it (mostly line plots but some box plots for categorical data). This required only a few changes such as adding a column for year or doing basic math, mostly wit dates, to get usable numbers for plots and correlation. There are some NAs in the data set, around 60 to 70 for each column. The highest one was 146 but that was Franchise which wasn’t really used in any analysis”

Tooling:


Packages: The packages used were:
bs4
ipykernel
lxml
matplotlib
numpy
pandas
requests
scikit-learn
shap
Environments: The virtual environment UV was used for this project with Python 3.13.
Reproducibility Steps: Run totality() to reproduce our dataset, results, and interpretation, for more details see the tutorial

title: Technical Report
text:
Results & Diagnostics
_TODO: Summarize the main metrics, charts, or model diagnostics produced. Include links to figures or tables once available._ Main Metrics: The main metrics for the plots and data of importance are as follows: General Movie Revenue: mean = 9.1 e^7 sd = 1. e^8 Season of Release: spring has the highest revenue (there isn’t a significant difference between any except for summer and fall summer is better (0.011)) fall: mean = 5.5 e^7, sd = 7.17 e^7 winter: mean = 7.9 e^7, sd = 7.62 e^7 spring: mean = 9.3 e^8, sd = 1.3 e^8 summer: mean = 1.493 e^8, sd = 1.8 e^8
Genre:
    the highest means are in 'Musicals', 'Action', 'Adventure' with means and sd of
    Musicals: mean = 1.6 e^8 ,sd = 1.8 e^8
    Action:   mean = 1.9 e^8 ,sd = 2.18 e^8
    Adventure:mean = 1.88 e^8,sd = 1.78 e^8

Movie Rating:
    PG: mean = 1.2 e^8 ,sd = 1.5 e^8
    R: mean = 5.5 e^7  ,sd = 6.4 e^7

Production Method:
    Animation/ Live Actin: mean = 1.58 e^8 ,sd = 1.68 e^8
    Digital Animation:     mean = 2.1 e^8  ,sd = 1.7 e^8
Charts:
Model Diagnostics: MSE Cross Validation Variable and Prepositions Plot

title: Technical Report
text:
Discussion & Next Steps
_TODO: Interpret the results, note limitations, and capture open questions or future experiments._ Results:
Limitations: The categorical and numerical analysis for correlation can’t show causation so we don’t know if adjusting one will directly influence the other. Additionally, none of the results shown significance, this means that the variance of revenue in any of our analyses is not different form the average mean.
Open Questions:
Future Experiments: In order to reduce the amount of variance it would be smart to separate data more, an example might be only action movies in winter compared to adventure movies in winter. This would hopefully reduce the variance and create a more accurate analysis as well as show any influence between variables, for example if R movies earning less revenue because most of them were released in winter. An analysis of movie ratings for these movies would also be informative as to what watchers value and there for what you could charge more for.

title: Documentation
text:
Functions: data_creation() This function requires no parameters. This function creates a new dataset from scratch by scraping the web, specifically the websites of wikipedia and the-numbers. It saves a pandas dataframe of this dirty data as a csv under the title ‘dirty_data.csv’. Then it takes the dataframe and cleans the data. It also adds the new columns Season and Profit. It saves this new clean pandas dataframe as a csv under the title ‘movie_data.csv’.
print_dataset_head() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function prints out the first five rows of the csv, as a pandas dataframe, for viewing.
getNAs() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function returns the number of NA values in each column/feature of ‘movie_data.csv’.
earnings_correlation() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function returns the correlation matrix between all numerical features.
season_earnings() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function returns a boxplot showing total box office revenue as grouped by seasons, and saves that graph as a png.
genre_earnings() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function returns a boxplot showing total box office revenue as grouped by genre, and saves that graph as a png.
production_method_earnings() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function returns a boxplot showing total box office revenue as grouped by production method, and saves that graph as a png.
ratings_earnings() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function returns a boxplot showing total box office revenue as grouped by ratings, and saves that graph as a png.
season_significance() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This functions returns the F value and p value of Season as in regards to Inflation Adjusted Domestic Revenue, (to ensure inflation doesn’t mess up our numbers), and the statistical significance between the various seasons.
rating_significance() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This functions returns the F value and p value of Rating as in regards to Inflation Adjusted Domestic Revenue, (to ensure inflation doesn’t mess up our numbers), and the statistical significance between the various ratings.
genre_significance() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This functions returns the F value and p value of Genre as in regards to Inflation Adjusted Domestic Revenue, (to ensure inflation doesn’t mess up our numbers), and the statistical significance between the various genres.
production_method_significance() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This functions returns the F value and p value of Production Method as in regards to Inflation Adjusted Domestic Revenue, (to ensure inflation doesn’t mess up our numbers), and the statistical significance between the various methods.
describe_revenue() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This functions returns a statistical description of the various types of revenue.
graph_revenue() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function returns a graph showing total box office revenue over time, and saves that graph as a png.
graph_revenue_by_year() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function returns a graph various revenues over time, grouped by year, and saves that graph as a png.
graph_revenue_and_profit() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function returns a graph showing Total Box Office Revenue and Profit over time, and saves that graph as a png.
analyze_revenue() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function runs describe_revenue, graph_revenue, graph_revenue_by_year, and graph_revenue_and_profit all at once.
factors_analysis() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function runs get_NAs, earnings_correlation, season_earnings, ratings_earnings, genre_earnings, production_method_earnings, season_significance, rating_significance, genre_significance, and production_method_significance all at once.
factors_findings() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function returns our interpretation and analysis of the feature graphs and the ones of statistical significance.
revenue_findings() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function returns our interpretation and analysis of the revenue graphs.
do_ml_analysis_plots() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function utilizes machine learning techniques, specifically the library shap, to create plots demonstrating the significance of various features during different stages of a movie’s release. These plots are saved as a png.
do_ml_analysis_numbers() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function utilizes machine learning techniques to create return numbers demonstrating the significance of various features during different stages of a movie’s release.
ml_analysis_findings() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function returns our findings and interpretation of the data from do_ml_analysis_plots and do_ml_analysis_numbers.
do_analysis_specific() This function requires no parameters. However, data_creation must be ran before this function can be used since it requires ‘movie_data.csv’. This function states our research question, and utilizes factors_analysis, factors_findings, do_ml_analysis_plots, and ml_analysis_findings, to provide an answer to that question. All of this is printed out into the terminal.
totality() This function gathers, cleans, analyzes, and interprets the data. Specifically is performs the functions of data_creation and do_analysis_specific at the same time.
